Expectation1: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation1: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: I stood in the crowded hall, the aroma of unfamiliar dishes swirling around me. My stomach grumbled, but I knew none of the food was kosher. I’d tried to prepare, but the event ran late, and my emergency snacks were long gone. As I scanned the buffet, my phone buzzed. It was the legislative aide—finally, after weeks of waiting, she had ten minutes to talk about the bill I’d poured my heart into. This was the moment I’d been working toward as an activist, a chance to make real change. But the only quiet spot was at the far end of the room, right next to the buffet, where everyone was eating. I felt the eyes of my colleagues, expecting me to join in, to be part of the community. I felt the weight of my own expectations, too—my commitment to kosher, my promise to my family, my faith. My hands shook as I clutched my phone, torn between stepping away to take the call and risking awkward questions, or staying and missing the opportunity I’d fought so hard for. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which part of myself I could let down.
